title: Understanding VO2 Max
content: The science behind VO2 max, the difference between maximum aerobic capacity and efficiency, and insights from examples of extreme human performance, such as the recent attempts to break the 2-hour mark in the marathon.

title: Optimal Exercise Volume for Health
content: Optimal exercise volume for maintaining health, how to avoid acute and chronic injuries, how to diversify your exercise portfolio, HIIT protocols, and much more.

title: Influence of Brain on Endurance
content: How the brain influences the limits of endurance.

title: Exercise Volume and Health
content: Relationship between exercise volume and health: Minimum dose, optimal dose, and whether too much exercise can shorten lifespan.

title: Age-Associated Decline in Aerobic Capacity and Muscle Mass
content: Age-associated decline in aerobic capacity and muscle mass, and the quick decline with extreme inactivity.

title: Importance of Strength or Muscle Mass
content: Strength or muscle mass—which is more important?

title: Avoiding Injuries from Exercise
content: Avoiding acute and chronic injuries from exercise.

title: High Intensity Interval Training
content: High intensity interval training: Evolution of the Tabata protocol, pros and cons of HIIT training, and how it fits into a healthy exercise program.

title: Understanding Purpose of Exercise
content: The importance of understanding why you are engaging in exercise.

title: Alzheimer's Disease and Lifestyle Factors
content: Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative disease that may be impacted by factors such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, and omega supplementation. The breakdown of the blood-brain barrier is a significant factor in neurodegenerative diseases. Type 2 diabetes increases the risk of Alzheimer's disease. Omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) play a crucial role in brain health and prevention of neurodegeneration. Blood pressure is an important modifiable lifestyle factor that can affect Alzheimer's disease risk.

title: Exercise and Alzheimer's Disease
content: Exercise may reduce the risk of Alzheimer's disease through various mechanisms. Building aerobic capacity has neurobiological effects and benefits of lactate peaks. Maximizing mitochondrial biogenesis through alternative training approaches and strategies can also be beneficial. The relationship between cardiorespiratory fitness and dementia risk is significant.

title: Sauna and Brain Health
content: Sauna use may have potential brain benefits. However, more research is needed to confirm these benefits and establish a personal protocol.

title: Exercise and Cancer Risk
content: Exercise may reduce the risk of cancer. The overarching impact of exercise on health is significant, and it is important to focus on the factors that matter most.

title: Alcohol Consumption and Cancer Risk
content: Alcohol consumption can impact breast cancer risk and overall health.

title: Exercise and Sleep
content: Exercise can be used as an intervention for poor sleep habits.

title: Protein Consumption and Longevity
content: Consuming adequate protein and strength training to preserve muscle mass and strength can have longevity benefits. It is important to get enough of the right kind of protein in your diet.

title: Fasting and Health
content: Fasting can have health benefits, but it is important to weigh the risk vs. reward.

title: Understanding VO2 Max
content: VO2 max is a measure of how quickly you can take oxygen from the air into your lungs, get it into your blood, pump it to your muscles, and then have your muscles use it in the metabolic processes that will provide energy to move you. It was first discussed/measured in the 1920s by a guy named A.V. Hill. VO2 max does NOT tell you exactly how fast you can run, but it tells you what sort of aerobic engine you have to play with. The amount of oxygen reaching any given muscle cell may actually be lower. VO2 max numbers are typically reported in milliliters of oxygen per minute, per kilogram of body weight. At every stage of the way, there can be limitations if anything is knocked off kilter.

title: The Case Study of Oskar Svensson
content: Oskar Svensson was a former downhill skier who had taken a talent screening to see whether he’d be suitable for something like cycling. At age 17, completely untrained, he scored something like 74 milliliters per kilogram per minute in VO2 max. He started training as a cyclist as a teenager and pretty quickly scored 83, then 85, then 92. Then, a scientific journal was eventually published saying his score was 96.7 when he was 18 years old. This is not only the highest recorded score in human history, but it’s also higher than all the rumors. However, he wasn't successful in his cycling career. The more he trained, the less efficient he got, meaning he could deliver more aerobic energy, but he used more aerobic energy in order to maintain a given pace.

title: The Relationship Between VO2 Max and Efficiency
content: There is a long-standing debate about whether there is an inverse relationship between VO2 max and efficiency. If you just take a bunch of elite athletes and you measure their VO2 max, you tend to see an inverse relationship — The people who have the highest VO2 max tend to have slightly lower, slightly worse economies. People that have the best economy, tend to have slightly worse VO2 max. There are two possible explanations for this phenomenon: You don’t tend to hit the lottery twice, meaning if you happen to have a VO2 max that’s 92, then you’re not going to have the best possible economy. The other possibility is that there’s actually a trade off—if you’re optimizing one physiological parameter it may come at the cost of the other physiological parameter.

title: Cell Level Explanation of Enzymes and Training
content: If you’re doing a lot of training that requires very high VO2 max level outputs, your metabolism and your cells need to make choices to produce high output, instead of to be as efficient as possible. Over time, you’ll get better at high output and lose efficiency. You’ll pay a slight penalty for optimizing your training for VO2 max.

title: Training Volume and Efficiency
content: Spending a lot of time in the 300 to 400 watt range could be optimized to the 300 watt range where you’re still just under two millimole of lactate, but you’re dramatically increasing mitochondrial efficiency. If that zone 2 work represented two thirds of your training volume, you’d likely have a lower VO2 max, but you might have been a better cyclist.

title: Marathon Running and Optimized Courses
content: Marathons are run in a very uncontrolled environment which differs from race to race. Yet, if it’s going to happen, it’s going to happen on an optimized course — one that optimizes for temperature, terrain, curvature, etc.

title: Advancement in Running Shoes
content: Technology is baked into the improvement curve, changes in circumstances, environment and technology are baked into those curves right from the get go. The world records have been absolutely knocked silly in the last two years, since these shoes have become common.

title: Brain's Influence on Endurance
content: When you exercise as hard as you can, the reason you stop or slow down is not because your legs aren’t capable of going faster, it’s because your brain is protecting you. This got him interested in role of the brain in the limits of human performance.

title: Exercise Volume and Health
content: Endurance based exercise is still an important pillar of health. Many people misinterpret their body’s distress signals. Get to a place where you understand that the feelings of discomfort are not signs that something is going wrong with your body, but they are just information.

title: Minimum Effective Dose of Exercise
content: A few studies came out and showed that the dose you need to get most of the health benefits is very small — I.e., you do not need to train for a marathons in order to be optimally healthy.

title: Optimal Exercise Routine
content: The Cooper Clinic study looked at 50,000 people or so and their number was 5 to 10 minutes a day (an hour a week). However, this lacks any high intensity cardio or strength training. For optimal health, it is suggested to run about 20 miles a week, six days a week, half an hour with a couple of hard days. It is also suggested to add more strength training to the routine.

title: Exercise and Injury Prevention
content: 5 to 10 minutes a day is a good place to start if you’re the 45 year old sedentary getting back into it. If you’re doing 60 minutes a week, it is suggested not to do 10 minute chunks, but rather at least 20 min at a time. Metabolically unfit individuals are likely to gain metabolic fitness more quickly than they improve/strengthen ligaments, tendons, and muscle strength. This is important to keep in mind so that you progress slowly to allow those aspects to catch up to aerobic fitness.

title: Exercise and Longevity
content: Exercising too much is less of an idea that the issue of having a lousy portfolio of various exercise types. Training for a marathon may not be bad, but it’s an opportunity cost of other things you could be doing that would probably work better in pursuing longevity. There are other potential issues with lots of endurance training, such as arrhythmias. So there may be downsides to training really hard.

title: Social Exercise
content: One study suggested tennis and badminton were associated with the most longevity largely due to that social interaction in those activities.

title: Age-associated Decline in Aerobic Capacity and Muscle Mass
content: With muscle, there’s an inevitability of decline. If you do nothing, you’re going to lose X pounds of muscle per decade if you’re lucky with a tailwind. If you train really hard, you might be able to reduce it to X amount of loss. If you really go hard, you might even be able to keep it flat. With aerobic capacity, there are tables that predict decline, but the problem with the tables is that they draw a nice smooth line. According to the table, you lose something like 9% per decade until you get into your seventies when it gets even steeper.

title: Impact of Extreme Inactivity
content: If you stop training for one full month, you may lose up to 10-20% of your exercise capacity. But it really depends where you’re starting. If you’re well-trained for a short period of time, you’ll lose it quickly. If you haven’t been training, then resting doesn’t make any difference. And if you’re well-trained over a long period of time, then you have structural adaptations that are going to take a lot longer to disappear.

title: Strength or Muscle Mass
content: Strength was actually a better predictor than muscle mass for all-cause mortality. In other words, it’s better to have the functionality than it is to have a bunch of muscle if you’re not good at using it.

title: Avoiding Acute and Chronic Injuries from Exercise
content: 80% of running injuries are a result of what would be called “training errors”. Most of what we need to worry about is doing too much too soon. You can gain metabolic fitness more quickly than you can alter the structure of your joints and ligaments.

title: High Intensity Interval Training
content: For someone who is not a specific athlete who’s training to run the mile or the marathon, but the person who’s trying to be healthy, intervals can help in terms of efficiency. Using the Tabata interval as an example, you’re going all out for 20 seconds, resting for 10, and repeating it eight times. Intervals are super important for a healthy exercise routine.

title: High Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) Discussion
content: Skepticism exists that four seconds at the intensity required for those intervals is more acceptable to the average person than, say, one full minute. The very first HIIT protocol was the Wingate test, which is 30 seconds all out and can make people feel sick. Protocols like 60 seconds on, 60 seconds off came from the thought that it’s easier for people to accept 60 seconds of hard work than it is to expect them to exert themselves fully in 30 seconds. Because, in reality, you have to be 100% on to get the most out of this “four-second” or “ten-second” interval stuff. There’s a lot of debate understandably about what it is that people will actually do—Would they rather do 20 minutes at medium, or 40 minutes easy, or four seconds hard?

title: Understanding the Purpose of Exercise
content: A lot of people aren’t clear on why they are engaging in exercise. If you’re thinking about the 90-year-old version of you in a chair—He needs to be able to get up—that gives you the motivation to do strength training. Once you stop competing in something, all this exercise stuff becomes abstract. Your body’s natural ability to fight off cancer when you’re fit is a much easier task than fighting cancer when you’re unfit simply based on the energetics of your immune system.

title: Critique of Science Journalism
content: Most of the articles are just sensationalized headlines and lack detail. A news story should be written with the understanding that very few people are going to go back to the primary source and read it … and this places an enormous responsibility on scientific journalism. Journalism now follows the audience. This was one of the great catastrophes of journalism in some ways because it’s unhealthy for the news organizations to find out what people click on. To encourage good science journalism, you need people to read good science journalism. News organizations aren’t going to insist on scientifically qualified journalists unless there’s repercussions or feedback when there’s bad journalism. The initial signals were the opposite—i.e., the less complicated it was and the more sensational it was, the more clicks they got. One possible solution: We need to move away from advertising and towards subscription-based models.
